ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Strongly suggested by asymmetric SNHL, significant rollover (0.76), absent ipsilateral reflexes, 83% unilateral vestibular weakness, and facial weakness indicating CN VII/VIII compression.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss (idiopathic)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initial presentation consistent with sudden SNHL, though retrocochlear signs point to specific tumor etiology.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration.
To assess speech discrimination and check for rollover.
To assess reflex pathways; absence can indicate retrocochlear pathology.
To evaluate cochlear outer hair cell function and differentiate cochlear vs retrocochlear site.
To assess postural stability and differentiate central vs vestibular pathology.
To evaluate vestibular system function and identify site of lesion.

ordered_list.action: MRI of internal auditory canals with and without contrast
ordered_list.rationale_short: To confirm or rule out retrocochlear lesion given multiple red flags.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiologic evaluation reveals mild high-frequency SNHL in the right ear with asymmetry (15-25 dB poorer at 2-6 kHz) and significant rollover (RI=0.76), strongly suggesting retrocochlear pathology. Absent ipsilateral ARTs on the right further support this impression. DPOAEs present bilaterally consistent with intact cochlear function. Vestibular testing shows severe right unilateral weakness (83% RVR) with left-beating nystagmus post-headshake (peripheral pattern) and postural instability on conditions requiring vestibular input. Findings highly suspicious for right vestibular schwannoma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Normal sloping to mild SNHL at 6-8 kHz. Left ear: Normal sloping to slight SNHL at 6-8 kHz. Interaural asymmetry of 15-25 dB HL at 2000, 4000, and 6000 Hz (right poorer).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 10 dB HL, Left 5 dB HL (normal bilaterally). WRS: Right ear shows significant rollover (68% at 40 dB SL dropping to 16% at 75 dB HL; Rollover Index 0.76). Left ear WRS 100% at 45 dB HL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type A bilaterally. Normal middle ear pressure, ear canal volume, and compliance.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral ARTs: Absent in Right ear at 500-4000 Hz; Present in Left ear (95, 90, 90 dB HL at 500, 1K, 2K Hz). Contralateral ARTs: Not performed due to equipment limitations.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAE)
tests.result_summary: Present and robust at 1600-7100 Hz bilaterally; absent at 8000 Hz bilaterally. Consistent with audiometric thresholds and suggests intact cochlear function.

tests.name: Gans Sensory Organization Performance (SOP)
tests.result_summary: Vestibular pattern of abnormality. Falls on Condition 4 (tandem stance, eyes closed) and Condition 6 (foam, eyes closed). Rightward deviation on Fukuda stepping test.

tests.name: VNG (Videonystagmography)
tests.result_summary: Caloric: 83% reduced vestibular response (RVR) right ear. High-frequency headshake: Left-beating nystagmus (peripheral pattern). Spontaneous nystagmus: Absent. Horizontal gaze: Normal. Oculomotor (saccades, pursuit, OPK): Within normal limits. Dix-Hallpike: Negative bilaterally. Positional: Normal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: MRI confirmed right vestibular schwannoma. Decision made to proceed with Gamma Knife radiosurgery.

tests.name: MRI internal auditory canals with/without contrast
tests.result_summary: 6-mm vestibular schwannoma within the right internal auditory canal, protruding into the cerebellopontine angle, compressing cranial nerves VII (facial) and VIII (vestibulocochlear).

treatment_and_management.treatment_rationale: Gamma Knife radiosurgery selected to halt tumor growth while preserving residual hearing; avoids surgical risks of complete hearing loss in right ear.
counseling_actions: Explain retrocochlear findings (tumor compressing CN VIII)
Discuss rollover (louder speech becomes less clear due to neural involvement)
Explain vestibular weakness and contribution to imbalance
Advise hearing protection in noisy environments (firing range)
Discuss importance of VRT for occupational fitness requirements as police officer

escalation.rationale_short: Immediate ENT follow-up for MRI due to facial weakness and multiple retrocochlear signs strongly suggesting vestibular schwannoma.

follow_up_plan.objective: Follow-up audiometric evaluation post-Gamma Knife surgery. Annual evaluations thereafter if stable.

expected_outcome: Patient completed Gamma Knife surgery in August 2016.
Neurologist will monitor tumor size with serial MRIs.
Patient referred for Vestibular Rehabilitation Therapy (VRT) to aid central compensation.
Scheduled for 6-month follow-up audiometric evaluation in February 2017.
If stable, annual audiologic monitoring thereafter.
